list_page_teaser: Do the incredibly gracious and wonderfully enchanting Little Edie and Big Edie have similar personalities, or are they opposites?  Click to find out!
description_html:
The Beales of Grey Gardens are kind of opposites, and kind of the same.

Between them they have all four of the core personality functions — iNtuition (Blue), Sensation (Yellow), Feeling (Red), and Thinking (Green) — covered. So as long as they respect each others' differences, they make an excellent team.

But they are the same in that they are both Extraverted and Perceiving, making them both outgoing and open-minded — in a word, delightful!
story_html:
I saw Grey Gardens for the first time on the big screen at the Sie FilmCenter here in Denver. It was a special occasion and I had no idea what I was in for.

The Beales' voices echoed in my mind for a week. This is extremely rare — an excellent film might continue to affect me for a day — so the film made a huge impression on me!

These profiles are based on the original film and the follow-up only, not the remake (even though the remake does an excellent job of extending rather than distorting the real thing).

Their Extraversion explains why they sometimes seem to compete for attention from the filmmakers. This sometimes deteriorates into bickering, but even then it's fun to watch.

And it's easy to see how some people — relatives, for example — might sense their openness, and try to condescend or even take advantage. These people are in for a big surprise, however, because beneath the surface, Little Edie is most definitely a Staunch Character!

If you have not seen this historic film, I cannot recommend it highly enough. It's easy to find online, but I was able to find it in the Denver Public Library, so I could watch it over and over, and share it with some friends.

image_list.title: Little Edie Bouvier Beale
image_list.subtitle_html: Famous Daughter in Grey Gardens
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: The Blue in this spiritual portrait represents Little Edie's openness to ideas, and the Red shows that she tends to respond with warmth and emotion.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Blue in this spiritual portrait represents Little Edie's dominant trait, her idealism.  In Extraverts, the dominant function is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  She exhibits this trait when she mentions she sees herself as being still a child - and we can see this in her often rather childish behavior!
image_list.explain_aux: The Red in this spiritual portrait represents Little Edie's auxiliary trait, her passion.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary function is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  She exhibits this trait in her reactions to the way their relatives and the townsfolk talk about and treat them.
image_list.story_intro_html: Of the two stars in this film, it's easiest to fall in love with Little Edie. Unfortunately, I'm not a ....
image_list.story_html:
Of the two stars in this film, it's easiest to fall in love with Little Edie. Unfortunately, I'm not a Libra but a Scorpio.

After seeing the original film (released in 1975) on that fateful day, I learned there are actually two other movies: The Beales of Grey Gardens, which was released in 2006 and contains additional footage from the original shooting, and the 2009 remake that stars Jessica Lange and Drew Barrymore — who both deliver outstanding performances.

Whenever possible, I recommended that my friends see Grey Gardens (usually without going into details about the different versions). If you have missed one or more of them, I strongly recommend that you check out all three — preferably in the sequence in which they were made.

And if you only have time for one, the original is still the best!

image_list.title: Big Edie Bouvier
image_list.subtitle_html: Famous Mom in Grey Gardens
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents Big Edie's pragmatism, and the Green shows that she tends to respond reasonably.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents Big Edie's dominant trait, her pragmatism.  In Extraverts, the dominant function is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  She exhibits this trait when she bickers with Edie about finances.
image_list.explain_aux: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents Big Edie's auxiliary trait, her rationality.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary function is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  She exhibits this trait by her determination to stay in the house, despite all the challenges.
image_list.story_intro_html: Of the two stars in this film, Big Edie is the one who commands respect. She has a tendency to be ....
image_list.story_html:
Of the two stars in this film, Big Edie is the one who commands respect. She has a tendency to be bossy, and she writes the checks.

After seeing the original film (released in 1975) on that fateful day, I learned there are actually two other movies: The Beales of Grey Gardens, which was released in 2006 and contains additional footage from the original shooting, and the 2009 remake that stars Jessica Lange and Drew Barrymore — who both deliver outstanding performances.

Whenever possible, I recommended that my friends see Grey Gardens (usually without going into details about the different versions). If you have missed one or more of them, I strongly recommend that you check out all three — preferably in the sequence in which they were made.

And if you only have time for one, the original is still the best!
